claim: If X is a proper subset of Y, and Y has more elements than X, then Y ≠ X

supporting.text: By definition, a proper subset X of Y means every element of X is in Y, but Y contains at least one element not in X, so Y ≠ X.

attacks.text: By definition, a proper subset X of Y means every element of X is in Y, but Y contains at least one element not in X, so Y ≠ X.

If Y is an infinite set and X is a proper subset of Y, it is possible for X and Y to have the same cardinality (e.g., natural numbers and even numbers), which may lead to confusion about whether Y ≠ X in terms of size.
Even if X and Y have the same cardinality in infinite cases, the definition of a proper subset still requires Y to contain an element not in X, so Y ≠ X holds regardless of cardinality.

supporting.text: If Y has more elements than X and X is a proper subset, then Y must include elements outside X, making Y distinct from X.

attacks.text: If Y has more elements than X and X is a proper subset, then Y must include elements outside X, making Y distinct from X.
If X and Y are infinite sets, the concept of 'more elements' becomes ambiguous, as cardinality comparisons may not align with subset relations.
Even for infinite sets, if X is a proper subset of Y, Y must contain at least one element not in X by definition, ensuring Y ≠ X.
In non-standard set theories (e.g., with urelements or multisets), the definition of 'proper subset' and element count may not guarantee Y ≠ X.
Standard ZFC set theory explicitly defines proper subsets to exclude equality, making the original claim universally valid in conventional mathematics.

supporting.text: Set theory states that two sets are equal only if they have identical elements; since Y has elements not in X, Y ≠ X.

attacks.text: Set theory states that two sets are equal only if they have identical elements; since Y has elements not in X, Y ≠ X.
If X and Y are infinite sets, the notion of 'more elements' becomes ambiguous due to different cardinalities, potentially undermining the argument.
Even for infinite sets, the definition of set equality (identical elements) remains unambiguous, so Y ≠ X still holds if Y contains elements not in X.
The argument assumes X is a proper subset of Y, but this premise could be contested if X and Y are defined in a non-standard way (e.g., partial sets).
Standard set theory definitions universally require identical elements for equality, regardless of non-standard interpretations of subsets.

supporting.text: The condition that Y has more elements than X directly implies a difference in cardinality, which means Y ≠ X.

attacks.text: The condition that Y has more elements than X directly implies a difference in cardinality, which means Y ≠ X.
If X and Y are infinite sets, they may have the same cardinality even if X is a proper subset of Y (e.g., natural numbers and even numbers).
The claim specifies 'has more elements,' which in standard set theory implies finite sets, where cardinality differences are unambiguous.
The term 'more elements' is ambiguous—it could refer to strict superset relations without explicit cardinality constraints.
In formal mathematics, 'more elements' is interpreted as strictly greater cardinality, removing ambiguity.

supporting.text: A proper subset relationship (X ⊂ Y) inherently means Y is strictly larger than X, so equality is impossible.

attacks.text: A proper subset relationship (X ⊂ Y) inherently means Y is strictly larger than X, so equality is impossible.
If X and Y are infinite sets, the concept of 'strictly larger' becomes ambiguous, as cardinalities of infinite sets can be equal even if one is a proper subset.

In standard set theory, infinite sets can indeed have proper subsets of the same cardinality, but this does not violate the original claim because the claim implicitly assumes finite sets where 'more elements' is well-defined.
The claim does not specify whether X and Y are finite or infinite, leaving room for ambiguity in interpretation.
Mathematical conventions typically assume finiteness unless stated otherwise, so the original claim is valid under standard interpretations.
